Mitigation Description: Disable or remove an RF transmitter

Mitigation Name: Discard RAN signaling received without integrity protection
Mitigation Description: User Equipment (UE) can reject for example RRC signaling such as RRC Release with Redirect info, if not integrity protected
where is it found?: FGT1562.501 Impair Defenses: Bid down UE

Mitigation Name: Cross check between application layer and transport layer
Mitigation Description: NFs such as NRF should cross check with TLS layer before issuing token to an NF
Employ a SMS Router that intercepts incoming location queries (from other operators), configured so that it can't be subverted

Physical protection of: communications centers, Telecommunications equipment room, Physically isolated operation areas, Equipment sited in other carrier's or partner's premises, cable/fibers, junction boxes, etc
Prevent insecure user profile configuration in network or UE
Subscription that includes unlimited data can prevent DoS due to exhausion of data plan limits

Mitigation Name: Monitor installed applications for data usage
Mitigation Description: On the UE, monitor installed applications for data usage and perform throttling if necessary
Services are refreshed periodically and/or terminated after completion of a request
Check if IMSI is served by the slice ID (NSSAI)
UDM/UDR should correctly implement UE authentication/registration status updates
UDM can check whether a requesting AMF is likely to be the one serving that UE
5G NFs should authorize API calls especially from external AFs for service accesses
Secure all subscriber databases in 5G network, for example,  Equipment Identity Register (EIR)
Increase RACH resources on the gNB (bandwith, time slots)

When the subscriber affiliation is reflected in the home network identifier (part of subscriber identifier), and would benefit from not being sent in the clear, the subscriber's provider (home network) should be a proxy mobile network operator - whose identifier does not reveal the true affiliation of the subscriber
Perform periodic authentication and authorization of consumer NFs by NRF
where is it found?: T1499.503 DOS a UE via gNB or NF signaling

Mitigation Description: Use strong data integrity protection algorithms
where is it found?:
T1565.002 Modify Data on SMO ext interfaces
T1565.002 Redirection of DNS requests
T1642.501 Endpoint Denial of Service: Transmit Spoofed Broadcast Message
FGT5009.002 Network Interfaces

Mitigation Description: Use zero trust principles for application/NF protection

Mitigation Name: Separate repositories for development and production
Mitigation Description: Separate repositositories must be maintained for development and production software to avoid access and image slipovers
Enforce strong mutual authentication methods between service providers and service consumers in the transport, core and O-RAN systems
UE warns user of lower security network

UDM/SIDF checks SUCI for freshness, whether it has been seen before, and for crypto parameters (example: if SUCI freshness parameter from the same UE (with same SUPI) is identical during SUCI deconcealment within a short period of time)
Network (AMF) should allocate new 5G-GUTI whenever possible; UPF and gNB should allocate unique Tunnel IDs; SMF should check newly allocated charging IDs
Verify if the TLS certificate is valid for the endpoint
Disable usage of location on UE device

Mitigation Name: Disable acceptance of a less secure system
Mitigation Description: Restrict UE to bid down (from 5G) or use of less secure system
Use UE only when needed Turn power off when not in use
Move UE close to gNB or indoors to make geo-location harder
Raising the height of the UE may move it outside another RF source, for example, jammer
Isolate CDR databases from the rest of the IT systems/NOC resources
Run at the UE side an application/tool to detect and not respond to silent SMS messages

Mitigation Name: Restrict access to operator OA&M resources
Mitigation Description: For example, restrict access to IR 21 database

Mitigation Name: TLS proxy/firewalls with DPI on the SBA
Mitigation Description: Operator should deploy TLS proxies or firewalls on the SBA that can inspect packets to detect anomalies

Mitigation Name: Increase control of home network for user plane
Mitigation Description: Examples: employ home routing vs local bypass
Cloud compute, cloud storage and any serverless activity should be isolated from other tenants
Hardware mediated  execution environment

Use of Network Slice Templates -Use of templates for network slicing can enforce baseline security and isolation requirements  These templates can be created for networks, compute and 5G slice functions deployments
Randomize TEID allocations

Mitigation Name: Screen signaling and user plane messages
Mitigation Description: Filter control plane and user plane messages to rate limit or block the ones with malicious contents
where is it found?:
FGT1499.002 UDM DOS via SUCI replay
FGT1599.505 Network Boundary Bridging: GTP-U Abuse
FGT1499 SMO Flood

Mitigation Description: Use high availability feature for all core network functions
Use Diameter End-to-end Signaling Security (DESS)
Minimize number of connections to eNB in NSA mode
Move mIAB node to another location to avoid RF jamming
Allow OAuth20 tokens with short lifetime to prevent AiTM attacks by replaying stolen tokens
Use application layer data obfuscation technique for example use of Orbot as Tor proxy to send all traffic through Tor circuit
Create and enforce resource policy; policy can include SLA, quotas, QOS etc
5G operators should integrate performance and change management from their suppliers into their own OA&M tools to have complete visibility into service
Enforce policy to use signed Software Bill of Materials (SBOMs) and software
Continuity of power supplies to equipment deployed in the field
Implement risk modeling of internal and external interfaces as part of architecture design and implement mitigations
Filter packets with unusual payloads

5G Operators should evaluate suppliers of services for their technical and administrative controls to ensure that it meets minimum standards for assured services; These evaluations may include SW, HD supply  chain, personnel and process used for service creation

Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc, to identify potential weaknesses; Perform periodic integrity checks of the device to validate the correctness of the firmware, software, programs, and configurations; Integrity checks, which typically include cryptographic hashes or digital signatures, should be compared to those obtained at known valid states, especially after events like device reboots, program downloads, or program restarts
Install security updates in response to discovered vulnerabilities
APIs in the system should use secure access and data transport using TLS v13 or latest

A variety of methods exist that can be used to enable enterprises to identify compromised (for example, rooted/jailbroken) devices, whether using security mechanisms built directly into the device, third-party mobile security applications, enterprise mobility management (EMM)/mobile device management (MDM) capabilities, or other methods; Some methods may be trivial to evade while others may be more sophisticated

In order to mitigate Signaling System 7 (SS7) exploitation, the Communications, Security, Reliability, and Interoperability Council (CSRIC) describes filtering interconnections between network operators to block inappropriate requests
Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them
Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction
Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts
Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity

Restricting web-based content involves enforcing policies and technologies that limit access to potentially malicious websites, unsafe downloads, and unauthorized browser behaviors This can include URL filtering, download restrictions, script blocking, and extension control to protect against exploitation, phishing, and malware delivery
Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts

Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures
Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root
Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts

Operating System Configuration involves adjusting system settings and hardening the default configurations of an operating system (OS) to mitigate adversary exploitation and prevent abuse of system functionality Proper OS configurations address security vulnerabilities, limit attack surfaces, and ensure robust defense against a wide range of techniques
Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information

Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources; Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information; Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network; Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems
Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries
Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator
Block users or groups from installing unapproved software
Block users or groups from installing or using unapproved hardware on systems, including USB devices

Mitigation Name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Mitigation Description: Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc
Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic
Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking
Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems; This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc behavior
Protect sensitive information with strong encryption

Mitigation Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Mitigation Description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries
Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping
Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing
Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms
Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc to identify potential weaknesses
Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system
Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software
Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring
Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk
Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise
Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates
This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques

Data Loss Prevention (DLP) involves implementing strategies and technologies to identify, categorize, monitor, and control the movement of sensitive data within an organization; This includes protecting data formats indicative of Personally Identifiable Information (PII), intellectual property, or financial data from unauthorized access, transmission, or exfiltration; DLP solutions integrate with network, endpoint, and cloud platforms to enforce security policies and prevent accidental or malicious data leaks
Mobile security products, such as Mobile Threat Defense (MTD), offer various device-based mitigations against certain behaviors
